etymologies: early 16th century; earliest use found in William Dunbar (?1460–?1530), poet and courtier. Probably from waly (although this is first attested later) + drag

definitions: A lazy, unkempt, or slovenly person; a good-for-nothing, a slob, a slattern.

notes.text: Chiefly as a mild term of abuse or contempt.

definitions: A weak, sickly, puny, or undersized person or animal.
The weakest, smallest, or youngest bird in a nest. Also: a person who is considered the weakest or youngest member of a family, group, etc.; the runt, the baby.
